content:
I've just edited the contribution:

Goal
* Fixed the typo per @darkdieg's comment below.

Tags
* Added "Chemistry".

Difficulty
* Kept the original assigned (not human-assigned) difficulty of Very Hard in view of the current success rate of 30%.

Very fun !
Just a typo in the last equation of the summary :
C6H12O6 + 6O2 -> 6CO2 + 6H20
Should be
C6H12O6 + 6O2 -> 6CO2 + 6H2O
Your solution code has been revised (see lines 64 to 70) because it does not produce the correct output to the newly added validator "Carbon tetrachloride".
Good job. I vote to approve. Nice puzzle.

Updated a minor point. (you're referencing arrows as if they were a character, which is mildly confusing considering they do exist as standard Unicode glyph, but aren't used here) (nor should they be)

Updated an even more minor point I'm not going to tell about since it's too small to notice.

And approved because it ticks all the checkboxes.

But I'm *not* pleased with the proliferation of linear system solving variants when only one language has had a relevant library installed.

I'm checking this one. I think that the description of molecule, equation and balanced equation should be in the goal section, and also have for example:
- Input: A chemical equation that can be balanced in only one way
- Output: The corresponding balanced equation
- Constraints: Each input will have only one way to balance the equation.
Checked with my own solution. It's challenging but very interesting. I just wait for an answer on my previous remark to approve it.

Unicode was intentionally avoided because I don't know enough about all the languates offered by CodinGame to anticipate if it would be an easily avoidable hurdle for certain users. The description does state that's it's given in ASCII and lists the sequence at the end of the line (visibility may be poor given the color scheme used for that highlighting).

NumPy was used because it was the simplest tool I could find in the language; it could probably also be compared to using explosives on an anthill. It's used for finding the RREF of the matrix which as far as I know is the quickest way to get a computer to solve a system of equations. For a pure python version see http://pastebin.com/GSgXkhr4 (diff https://www.diffchecker.com/nvKDPAsr ) which uses code from https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Reduced_row_echelon_form which also shows implementations for several languages, many of which don't require any libraries.

I believe this problem could be solved without any such mathmatical systems, and my first attempt at a solution was simply imcrement and check. Unfortunately attempting to naively brute-force the problem can result in loops which makes a math-based approach easier. When I had to do these sort of things manually in school I would never attempt such a system, especially by hand, but computers don't posses the same level of intuition a human does.

I think this problem may be harder than average, however I don't think that should be a seen as a detriment.

Yup, you did the right thing by avoiding Unicode. I merely cleared any potential confusion.

For linalg, please note I'm not berating you for using it in your solution, it does make total sense. I'm simply bemoaning the fact only one language currently has deployed support for it, which makes such class of problem unfairly (by whatever measure) biased towards Python.

FWIW, my reference implementation bruteforced, because it does pass, and I'm a bit fed up with reimplementing gaussian reduction over and over again.

Whoops, sorry for the delay, edited per suggestion and definitley looks much cleaner now.

I definitely thought this would be easier than it was to implement when I first started, but I knew it should be solvable.
